column1: spoonie-living 160881336400 "2017-05-20 19:00:43 GMT" http://blog.spoonieliving.com/post/160881336400/anyone-who-dissociates-semi-constantly-please "wolfinthethorns:  siavahdainthemoon:  I have now been told by two mental health professionals in two days that under NO CIRCUMSTANCES EVER am I to practice traditional Mindfulness exercises Apparently â€˜feeling like Iâ€™m dissolvingâ€™ and also that â€˜Iâ€™m rising out of my bodyâ€™
column2: and being passing-out-exhausted afterwards
column3: are all the complete OPPOSITE of whatâ€™s meant to happen Who knew??? But seriously - this is something that apparently happens to people who are low-key (or not so low-key) disassociating semi-constantly
column4: and is really really not good for you. So if youâ€™re one of those people
column5: like me! then there are other forms of mindfulness that may be more appropriate for you - specifically touch/sensation based
column6: rather than the guided-thinking
column7: breath- and sensory-focusing exercises that make up traditional mindfulness programs/exercises. Talk to your local health care professional if at all possible.Â  But basically
column8: if you know you have issues with disassociation
column9: and somebody recommends a mindfulness program to you
column10: BRING UP THE FACT THAT YOU DISASSOCIATE. Because normal mindfulness can be super bad for you. There ARE apparently mindfulness programs that can be helpful
column11: but they have to be catered to the disassociation. So. Please bear that in mind
column12: everybody.  To add: mindfulness practices are also contraindicated for people who experience psychosis
column15: and thereâ€™s debate over how safe they are for people who live with OCD.  We post a lot of stuff about mindfulness and related practices
column16: so this is a really important disclaimer! The world pushes a lot of self care practices
column19: or exercise. But remember that this sort of thing is not one-size-fits-all. Make the choices that make sense for you
column20: and definitely donâ€™t put yourself in a dangerous place just because a blog says so ğŸ˜œ" False text

column1: spoonie-living 160775508443 "2017-05-17 19:00:47 GMT" http://blog.spoonieliving.com/post/160775508443/cane-tips "louisamayanniecat: I saw a post going around about how there isnâ€™t a lot of help out there for adjusting to the new physical realities of using mobility aids
column2: so hereâ€™s one for canes. Cane-users
column3: please add any tips you have! 1. Get a cane that fits! Canes come in different sizes and some are adjustable. I use an adjustable metal cane which I purchased on the advice of my physiotherapist. He made sure it was adjusted to my size- right at where my wrist dangles 2. Get a cane youâ€™ll use! If you want to get specific about the colour
column4: material
column5: or feel
column6: go with your first choice because a cane purchase is a long lasting item in frequent use. It wonâ€™t help you if you wonâ€™t use it.  3. If youâ€™re using your cane for joint damage
column7: remember the rule good goes to heaven
column8: bad goes to hell. Not only a judgy religious concept! It simply means that when you climb stairs you step up with your better leg and down with your worse leg. 4. Pick a cane style thatâ€™s right for you. There are forearm crutch type cane
column10: canes with four prongs at the bottom
column12: etc. Talk to your doctor/physio/occupational therapist about what kind of cane is most useful for your situation. If you have trouble with your wrists
column14: a forearm cane or two might be better.  5. Use a wrist strap! Iâ€™m not good at bending or balancing or getting up
column15: so dropping my cane is an issue for me. I bought a cane with a bracelet wrist strap so if I need to let go I donâ€™t have to balance it precariously on something
column16: I can use my hands without worrying about dropping it @spooniestrong @spoonie-living @cripples-r-us-swag @cripplechronicles @flimsywrists
column18: especially the point that it wonâ€™t help you if you wonâ€™t use it.Our additions:6. Consider how â€œmedicalâ€ you want your cane to look. A cane is a great way to signal that you need extra time
column20: or help: if your disability isnâ€™t visible
column21: you can use your mobility device to communicate that. A metal cane with foam handle might be a clearer signal than
column23: a fancy wooden cane or walking stick that could be mistaken for a fashion statement. 7. Make sure youâ€™re having fun with it. Pick a pattern you like
column24: add a charm to the wrist loop
column25: find some cute stickersâ€¦ make it yours! You can find some fun mod ideas under our DIY tag and Mobility Aid tag. If your cane looks well-loved and well-used
column26: you may get the bonus effect of not getting those obnoxious â€œOh no
column27: what happened?â€ responses from random folks you encounter.8. If you donâ€™t use your cane all the time and could leave it somewhere by accident
column28: you may want to put a little â€œIf Foundâ€ sticker on it.Readers
column29: feel free to reblog with more!" False text

column1: spoonie-living 160272314792 "2017-05-03 19:01:04 GMT" http://blog.spoonieliving.com/post/160272314792/help-i-binged-what-do-i-do-now "recoveryisbeautiful: First
column2: Â know your binge. What caused it? How could you have better handled it? What alternatives are there to bingeing? What KIND of binge was it? Subjective vs. Objective Binges 3 Tips to Eat â€œNormallyâ€ Again Brain Over Binge: How I Stopped Acting on Urges Alternatives to Bingeing 10 Strategies for Overcoming Binge Eating Advantage/Disadvantage Chart for Unhealthy Behaviors Printout Now if youÂ is you DOÂ bingeâ€¦ because it does happen from time to time in recoveryâ€¦ here areÂ 20 reasons not to hate yourself after a bingeÂ [x]. column1: spoonie-living 159797912275 "2017-04-20 19:01:02 GMT" http://blog.spoonieliving.com/post/159797912275/disabled-cooking "lil-miss-choc:  spoonie-living:  #thatfeelingwhenâ€¦ youâ€™re low on spoons but you gotta get your grub on. The eternal struggle! Iâ€™ve certainly been there. I love cooking
column2: but all that standing and walking was really getting me down. So
column3: I got a couple of great pieces from Ikea
column4: and now cooking is way easier. Hereâ€™s what I do: 1) Keep a high chair in the kitchen. I live with 3 other people
column5: so I needed one that could be folded and tucked away as needed. For me
column6: the most important features were a backrest and a footrest
column7: so I settled on the FRANKLIN Bar stoolÂ ($45) from Ikea. Check it out in action: [Image description: A kitchen countertop
column8: with a stove
column10: and a cart full of food and dishes.] It puts me at just the right height for the counter
column11: and I can position it so I can reach the stove and the counter with no problems. Iâ€™ve also found that it slides pretty nicely on the floor without any scuffs
column12: so Iâ€™ll sometimes push myself around using the counters. PRO TIP: I always keep a water bottle with me when cookingâ€“thatâ€™s some hard work Iâ€™m doing
column13: and I gotta stay hydrated! Plus
column14: itâ€™s great to have a little water on hand; Iâ€™ll drip a little into the pan to get a feel for how hot my oil is
column15: or add a little when I need it for my recipe. [Image: A kitchen counter and sink
column16: with a high chair and a cart loaded with dirty dishes.] I can also use it for washing the dishes! Again
column18: so Iâ€™m good to go. This chair has been worth the price ten times over by now. You might be wondering about that cartâ€“and
column20: thatâ€™s the next part of my disabled cooking setup!Â  This is theÂ RÃ…SKOG utility cartÂ ($29.99)Â from Ikea: an item that I had been drooling over for years
column21: which just dropped in price from a whopping $80 (thank the Swedish gods!). I bought it for myself without a use in mind
column22: but once I got the chair I realized what a great addition this would make.Â  You see
column23: itâ€™s got wheels (albeit kind of dinky ones)
column25: so you can hit the fridge
column27: and cabinets to load up on all the things you need for your cooking adventure. Here was my setup for some yummy fried rice: [Image: A closeup of the loaded cart
column28: with a variety of foods and dishes piled on its three shelves.] All the foods and tools I need in one convenient spot! I transfer them over to the counter and stovetop as needed
column29: and then throw them back on the cart when Iâ€™m done. For example
column30: foods that need to go back to the fridge get the top shelf
column31: and dishes that need washing get the bottom. Then
column33: I just wheel it over to the fridge and the sink to clean up! The crowning glory to this setup
column35: is the small bins you see hanging from the edge of the cart. These are containers from Ikeaâ€™sÂ BYGEL series ($0.99 ea.).Â The black one is for regular trash
column37: and red is for recycling! I donâ€™t always use these
column38: but when I do they are super handy and keep me from having to walk around to various trash/recycle/compost bins. The only drawback is that these containers have small holes at the bottom
column39: so drippy compost is a little complicated. This could easily be solved with small composting bags
column41: or a number of other little fixes. There are probably some hanging containers more suited to this
column42: too. This whole setup has been treating me really well
column43: and can be adjusted for how Iâ€™m feeling and how complicated my recipe is. Lately
column44: Iâ€™ve been more mobile and have just been using the chair
column45: but I have everything I need if Iâ€™m tired or want to take on something big. I hope this inspires you to take control of your kitchen and get cookinâ€™! :)  I went to IKEA to try and find a high chair like this
column47: but got so exhausted I couldnâ€™t work out exactly what I wanted and ended up leaving it because I was in too much pain to think. Any tips on the best height for perching over a sink? How do you stop your knees knocking into the cabinets?  Eek
column48: sorry to hear you had such an unpleasant IKEA visit :â€™( For all its cheap furniture and yummy meatballs
column49: it sure is a special kind of a spoonie hell.Honestly
column50: the best height has a lot to do with how high your kitchen counters are and how tall your torso is. I think mine is the taller of the two
column51: and for perching over the sink I would expect that higher would be better.The knees thing is definitely a challenge
column52: and a bit inescapable if you want to be sitting in the kitchen. To reduce the impact
column53: I tend to sit at an angle to the counter
column54: with my dominant side closer in. But if youâ€™re better at bending forward than turning your torso
column55: you might find it easier to give yourself some extra knee room between the chair and the counter. Your mileage may vary on that one.Hope thatâ€™s useful!â€”Editor Diane" False text

column1: spoonie-living 159647191009 "2017-04-16 19:01:12 GMT" http://blog.spoonieliving.com/post/159647191009/scatteringmyashes-thatdiabolicalfeminist "scatteringmyashes:  thatdiabolicalfeminist:  Somebody once asked me
column2: a little horrified I think
column3: â€œWait - what are the bad parts of being neurotypical??â€  Iâ€™d made an offhand comment about how being autistic has good and bad parts
column4: just like being neurotypical has good and bad parts.  I think one the bad parts of being neurotypical is that you donâ€™t get so many of the amazing parts of being
column5: for example
column6: autistic. Neurotypical people can fidget
column7: for instance
column8: but they canâ€™t ever know how good it feels to have your body just flow into a stim
column9: to feel your thoughts start lining up or your body get comfortable when you stim the way you need to. Autistic people (and some others!) have this amazing experience where our bodies find motions that express and comfort and regulate in ways that neurotypical people can never fully understand. And neurotypical people can enjoy sensory experiences
column10: but to be autistic is to have a unique relationship with sensory input. So much of our sensory experiences are amplified compared to those of NTs
column11: and while that can and does cause overload etc. sometimesâ€¦ when the input is good? Itâ€™s glorious. Good fabrics and good sounds and good smells and good tastes and textures - we get to feel them all more intensely.  And echolalia! Echolalia is so good and so enjoyable and neurotypical people
column13: get only the barest shadow of what itâ€™s like.  NTs can have hobbies and passions and callings
column15: ever know the pure and consuming joy that is a special interest. There are good and bad parts to being autistic. Neurotypicals
column16: youâ€™re going to have to accept that
column17: and along with it the concept that autistic people have good experiences that you
column19: simply cannot have.  You donâ€™t see yourself as an object of pity because you lack those experiences
column20: do you? You arenâ€™t going to pour millions into research to have brains like ours
column22: even if you could do it
column23: you wouldnâ€™t be you anymore. And the way your brain works is just fine for you
column24: you donâ€™t mind not having good autistic experiences because you have your own!  Well - same. I donâ€™t want to be neurotypical. Being autistic is an integral part of my personality
column25: and I wouldnâ€™t give up my good autistic experiences for a shot at your neurotypical ones in a million years. What I want is to be accepted for who I am as an autistic person
column26: for people to respect and accommodate my needs the way the world respects and accommodates your needs as a neurotypical person.   Also special interests! Thereâ€™s nothing quite like having a thingÂ that you love and cherish and know so much about and I know I wouldnâ€™t be the same without all of my SIs.Â   Autistic & other neurodivergent folks
column27: hereâ€™s a reminder that you are great
column28: and that neurotypicals have goods and bads too
column29: regardless of what they might want to believe ğŸ˜‰" False text

column1: spoonie-living 159609998026 "2017-04-15 19:01:02 GMT" http://blog.spoonieliving.com/post/159609998026/a-good-phrase-for-mental-illness "insomniac-arrest: sometimes I see posts around tumblr about mental illness basically justifying shitty behavior as something ND people canâ€™t help and thus should be accepted/go uncontested
column2: which is not only fucked up but dehumanizing to people with ND I have to say a good phrase in order to take action to change habits and also assuage the guilt and shame that comes with ND isÂ â€˜while it is not my fault
column3: it is my responsibilityâ€™ my therapist taught me this phrase and I find it very relevant to restoring my power and seeing my actions not as inevitable and my choices as nonexistent
column4: but as something I canâ€™t always help
column5: but can always do something about the ability to feel like you have freedom of choice and personal agency is always key to recovery and tumblrÂ saying that these donâ€™t exist within ND people is very harmful and hurts not only our healthy coping tools but dehumanizes us by saying we are helpless to our own biology in all circumstances yes
column6: our actions can be limited
column7: but they are still ours
column8: and if â€˜with great power comes great responsibilityâ€™ holds true it means that we too still have power to shape our own future
column11: this is a great little nugget of wisdom and mantra for some of you struggling with the mental illness feels. The above should be helpful to those looking for a feeling of agency
column12: but please donâ€™t let it circle back around and guilt you when you do something you arenâ€™t proud ofâ€”messing up is a part of having agency and responsibility. Everybody does it. Just because itâ€™s related to your mental illness doesnâ€™t make it inherently more â€œwrongâ€ than a neurotypical screw-up. It doesnâ€™t make you a failure

column1: spoonie-living 159422859236 "2017-04-10 19:01:09 GMT" http://blog.spoonieliving.com/post/159422859236/dbt-skills-emotion-regulation "borderlinebravery: Skills List: Describe Emotions When Emotions Fit the Facts Accumulate Positives Opposite Action Problem Solving Build Mastery Cope Ahead Pain VS. Suffering PLEASE Mindfulness of Current Emotion  Managing Extreme Emotions (Skills Breakdown Point) What Are They? Emotion Regulation skills teach you how to control your emotions. Theyâ€™ll also help you effectively express your emotions as well as alter your emotional experiences when desired and/or necessary. Why Do You Need Them? Emotion Regulation is necessary for mental health. Harmful behavior patterns (suicidal acts
column2: eating disorders
column3: substance abuse issues
column4: unhealthy relationships
column5: etc.) are the result of faulty attempts of handling painful emotions. Emotion Regulation Aims To Help You: 1.) Increase awareness and understanding of emotions Understand the function of your emotions Identify obstacles to changing your emotions Identify and label your emotions 2.) Change unwanted emotions Check the facts of a situation Problem solveÂ  Apply opposite action to emotions 3.) Reduce vulnerability deriving from emotions Accumulate positive emotions Build mastery Learn to cope ahead Take care of your body 4.) Learn to effectively manage powerful emotions Be mindful of your current emotion Identify your skills breakdown point Source: 1. DBT Skills Training Manual Second Edition by Marsha Linehan (x)  Coping is hard sometimes
column6: but DBT (Dialectical Behavioral Therapy) is a freakinâ€™ godsend! You can find a therapist who specializes in this
column7: but if youâ€™re working on your own (or even if not!)
column8: youâ€™ll really benefit from reading up.Like this and want more? @howilearnedtocope posts great stuff in this vein!" False text

column1: spoonie-living 158449206303 "2017-03-15 21:31:14 GMT" http://blog.spoonieliving.com/post/158449206303/lifehack-makeup-remover-wipes "queerbabescully:  spoonie-living:  heyatleastitsnotcancer:  spoonie-living:  reganadler:  I literally only wear makeup to work

column7: hot foods/drinks make nausea worse and cold drinks  make it better.If you want to talk to a doctor about prescription  nausea mess
column8: I take Zofran and it has been a literal life saver. Â The  generic is called ondansetron. column1: spoonie-living 157952959134 "2017-03-03 20:00:41 GMT" http://blog.spoonieliving.com/post/157952959134/mylifeasbrittney-eevee-morgan "mylifeasbrittney:  eevee-morgan:  eevee-morgan:  to young disabled people: when i was younger i used to think i wasnâ€™t allowed to be picky about my relationships.  i thought that the only appropriate response to someone showing romantic interest in me was overwhelming gratitude - after all
column2: anyone who wanted to date a sick girl must be a saint
column3: right?  wrong. there are people who will fetishize your disability
column4: and there are people who will use you to show off how â€œgoodâ€ they are for deigning to date a disabled person. and (i didnâ€™t figure this out until i met my current partner) there are also people who will love you for who you are
column5: disability and all.   it is not a burden to love you
column6: and there are so many people out there who will do so without reservation. donâ€™t be afraid to look for them.  you are important
column7: and you deserve healthy
column8: happy love.  ğŸ’™  I learned the lesson this year after ending a two-year long relationship with extreme lows and mediocre highs. I gave my all to someone who gave me 10% 50% of the time. I have cut out so many toxic people from my life since then and I have really been focusing on me and doing things that I want to do. Iâ€™ve left my comfort zone time and time again - I feel so free now and Iâ€™m going to stay this way until Iâ€™m good & ready - until I meet someone who deserves me.  Gosh
column9: not to mention abusive partners! Donâ€™t let anyone make you feel like you are less for your disability
column10: that their abuse is the best you can hope for. Abusers will absolutely use your illness or disability against you
column11: whether it be direct or more subtle.Resources on relationship abuse (with a focus on emotional abuse):Warning Signs and Red Flags â€”via The National Domestic Violence HotlineThe Cycle of Abuse Theory â€”via Wikipedia21 Warning Signs of an Emotionally Abusive Relationship â€”via PsychCentralYouâ€™re Not Going Crazy: 5 Sure Signs Youâ€™re Being Emotionally Abused â€”via The Huffington PostAbuser Tricks and Warning Signs of Domestic Abuse â€”via New Hope For WomenAnd if youâ€™re a dude or nonbinary
column12: just an affirmation that despite the gendered nature of discourse on relationship abuse
column13: you can be abused and your experience matters just as much." False text

column1: spoonie-living 157745838360 "2017-02-26 20:00:53 GMT" http://blog.spoonieliving.com/post/157745838360/caffeinewitchcraft-thebibliosphere "caffeinewitchcraft:  thebibliosphere:  stimmymage:  pervocracy:  fandommember:  benaddictedcumberbabe:  cameronfryesgirlfriend:  cause of death: too shy to call ambulance  Didnâ€™t want to inconvenience anyone  Someone else might have needed it more  This happens. :( Bear in mind that ambulance companies arenâ€™t diverting EMTs away from a heart attack or traumatic amputation to answer your call. Â Theyâ€™re much more likely to be diverting EMTs from: Sitting in an ambulance station or a random parking lot playing Words With Friends and/or developing elaborate company-wide romantic intrigues Sitting in a hospital EMS room doing giant stacks of paperwork no one will ever read while trying to make dinner entirely out of saltines and condiments Routine transports of people who have to travel by stretcher
column2: who maybe are notÂ happy to be late
column3: but are hardly going to die from it Transports which are technically emergencies
column4: but are stuff like vomiting or a sprained ankle where the urgency factor is more like â€œyeah
column5: you should get that seenâ€ than like â€œSTAT CODE RED CODE BLUE CODE POLKA DOT STAT STAT STAT.â€ So if you think you might need an ambulance
column6: call one. Â You are not going to single-handedly take down the EMS system by daring to use it.  Iâ€™m reblogging it but I would be that person wondering â€œDo I need this enoughâ€ until I died.  I have legitimately done this. Please
column7: take care of yourselves.  Furthermore
column8: guys
column9: we have dispatch. Dispatch makes sure that weâ€™re all where we need to be
column10: so youâ€™re not taking an ambulance away from someone whoÂ â€œneeds it more.â€Â  Let dispatch worry if an ambulance needs to be somewhere else. You just worry about taking care of yourself.  Hilarious post followed by extremely important PSA. Our favorite! ğŸ˜‹" False text

column1: spoonie-living 157284141898 "2017-02-15 20:00:47 GMT" http://blog.spoonieliving.com/post/157284141898/things-i-wish-i-had-known-with-my-first-service "drovie:Itâ€™s been many years now
column2: since I first got a service dog. Thereâ€™s both a lot of helpâ€¦ and not a lot of helpâ€¦ for people who are looking to get set up with a service animal. So here are some of the things that Iâ€™ve learned since starting this venture. 1. Do not pay some website to â€˜certifyâ€™ your dog. The reason why is that there is no federal certification for service dogs. The companies youâ€™re paying literally just make little id tags. They donâ€™t mean your dog is really a service dog
column3: and they definitely wonâ€™t help you in court. 2. Training. Training. Training. Did I remember training? Training a dog yourself can be a rewarding experience
column4: but to be frank
column5: it may not actually be something you can accomplish on your own. And thatâ€™s okay. There are dog trainers out there who will do ALL of the training for you. 3. Get your doctor behind you 100%. This goes for when you have to swap doctors too. I learned that the first question I have to ask is â€˜are you okay with service animals in my medical treatmentâ€™. Youâ€™ll be surprised how many doctorâ€™s offices have NO CLUE about service animals
column6: at all. Try to find one that understands what goes into it
column7: theyâ€™ll be able to help you with making sure your dog helps your needs
column8: as well as provide you with paperwork that can come up later. 4. CHECK YOUR INSURANCE. Oh my god I wish I had known about this before. Zeus cost a fortune
column9: and often times we had to choose between regular bills
column10: and paying for Zeusâ€™ training and care. Some insurances
column12: etc. cover service animals and their gear. This is where your doctor having your back is important
column13: as the insurance company will usually require proof that you are disabled before they pay anything out. 5. There will be fake service dogs out there. And they will screw up your dog. Donâ€™t be afraid to remove yourself and your dog from the presence of a disruptive dog. 6. People will not always understand. Itâ€™s okay. Donâ€™t be afraid when they donâ€™t understand. Just make sure you got your own shit together. Thatâ€™s whatâ€™s important.  Getting a little more service dog info out there for our readers! This list is all about ways to get through the system as easily as possible
column14: without getting duped into spending more money or effort.See also: Am I Disabled Enough For My Service Dog?

column1: spoonie-living 160413644511 "2017-05-07 19:00:43 GMT" http://blog.spoonieliving.com/post/160413644511/living-with-chronic-illness-and-accepting-your "Perspective matters. A lot. The way we talk and this about our bodies and our illnesses can really impact how we feel about ourselvesâ€”and although the slights against ourselves might feel small
column2: they can snowball into some pretty bad feels.Kate the (Almost) Great gets the ball rolling with this really useful suggestion:â€¦identify what you are mad at â€“ because you are 100% allowed to feel mad  about your chronic illness. Be mad at the disease itself
column3: psoriatic  arthritis in my case. But donâ€™t blame your body as a whole. Now
column4: consider the differences between these statements:â€œMy body is hurting meâ€ vs. â€œIâ€™m in pain.â€â€œMy body is attacking meâ€ vs.Â â€œMy illness is attacking me.â€The same goes for self-deprecating humor. Something like â€œI sure made some bad decisions todayâ€ can really eat into your confidence when used frequently. Try instead
